column4: it means the chipset for the wireless card, not the actual model.
How can I detrmine the chipset of the NETGEAR Wireless PC Card WG511?
google seems to think the older wg511 are prism based,  where the newer ones are  atheros based
I googled that result myself before. My question remains as I cannot see if my card is older or newer.
you say the computer sees it?
or just lspci and read the output.

'~$ dmesg  | grep -i wg511' produces no output. Nor '~$ lspci | grep -i Wireless'. '~$lspci' produces the line: "02:00:0 Network controller: Intersil Corporation ISL3890 [Prism GT/Prism Duettel/ISL3886 [Prism Javelin/Prism Xbow] (rev 01)." How can I use this information for the  man iwconfig statement: "Please refer to the man page of each device for details."?
hmm.  so it is a prism xbox/javelin
I cannot put to good use your answer. I'd like to know how I can use the above statement to make good use of the man iwconfig statement: ""Please refer to the man page of each device for details."?
seems to be some issues with that card.  some suggestions saying use ndiswrappers (I don't know who to do that,sorry). this might help though...http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=701287
I do not need ndiswrapper because the present driver works.
ok sorry, thought you where having issues getting it to work
The driver is not prism54pci. The driver is prism54. --  I repeat my question: Where is the associated man page for it?
